content.title: Carotid Artery Dissection
content.definition: A tear in the wall of the carotid artery allowing blood to enter between arterial layers, creating an intramural hematoma that may cause stenosis, occlusion, or pseudoaneurysm formation.

concepts.definition: Causes and risk factors for carotid dissection.

clinical_features.spontaneous: Often associated with connective tissue disorders
clinical_features.associated_conditions: FMD, Marfan, Ehlers-Danlos Type IV, recent infection

concepts.definition: Signs and symptoms of carotid dissection.

clinical_features.horner_syndrome: Partial Horner's (miosis, ptosis) from sympathetic chain compression
clinical_features.cranial_nerve: Lower cranial nerve palsies in some cases

clinical_features.cta: First-line, shows intimal flap, mural hematoma, narrowed lumen
clinical_features.mri_mra: Excellent for intramural hematoma (T1 fat-sat), follow-up imaging
clinical_features.duplex: May show dissection flap, altered waveforms
clinical_features.dsa: String sign, tapered occlusion, pseudoaneurysm if present

clinical_features.anticoagulation: Heparin followed by warfarin for 3-6 months (traditional)
clinical_features.antiplatelet: Aspirin alternative, similar outcomes in CADISS trial
clinical_features.endovascular: Stenting for symptomatic stenosis despite medical therapy
clinical_features.surgical: Rarely needed, for pseudoaneurysm or failed medical management
clinical_features.follow_up: Serial imaging at 3-6 months to assess healing

clinical_features.prognosis: Most heal spontaneously, ~85% show improvement on imaging
